column8:
This game has kind of a sad history.  It looked REALLY good when it was on early access, and had a few people's support, but beyond the ship design most of it was clunky and hard to understand or manage.  I had a game once where I built a big ship and the only thing I could do was go into warp drive, because the other controls besides turning didn't seem to work.  I essentially hung dead in space.

I got this game for the ship design.  While it has an unfinished feel to it, the ship building looks cool enough and a lot of it had a bunch of potential.  I myself will likely install it once or twice just to build some ships again so that I get a visual idea for something for a much better game, like say Space Engineers.  Beyond that, however, I probably will never play it again.  It was a waste of potential.  Kind of wished that the devs put more effort into it...or at the very least got some help in finishing the game.

Sad day.  I hate making negative reviews.

column8:
I loved this game, and at times I would just spend hours designing the perfect ship of my dreams, giving each module a story and a purpose.  I would launch out in to space and sail in its vastness engaging in combat with the surrounding AI.. and this is where the fun really ends. I first bought this game when it released into Early Access. It was my last 20 bucks, and I sat there clenching my virtual steam funds... finally giving in. Kinetic Void looked like a very good game, the updates were coming fast, people were hyped showing each other their creations and the lore behind them.  Even a member of the Yogscast posted a video depicting the gamer designing and testing out a ship in his created system.

I played almost constantly, seeing what I could make next, and admiring other peoples' hard and dedicated work as well.  But then, suddenly the game is "released". I was quite shocked, I knew this couldn't be true... the game was a broken mess, did they finally refine the faction and trading system?  Is the combat more fluid and less buggy?  It seems they really haven't.  They left a note at the door. I was devastated, waiting two years in anticipation for all of these features.  I scanned the forums, witnessing developers deleting threads and banning customers asking sincere questions.  It saddens me, and I really thought this game was going to be a success, remembering the hype and positive feedback of the game in its Early Access release.  Hopefully other developers won't follow in their footsteps, but unfortunately it happens frequent enough.  Cheers.
column9:
I loved this game, and at times I would just spend hours designing the perfect ship of my dreams, giving each module a story and a purpose.  I would launch out in to space and sail in its vastness engaging in combat with the surrounding AI.. and this is where the fun really ends. I first bought this game when it released into Early Access. It was my last 20 bucks, and I sat there clenching my virtual steam funds... finally giving in. Kinetic Void looked like a very good game, the updates were coming fast, people were hyped showing each other their creations and the lore behind them.  Even a member of the Yogscast posted a video depicting the gamer designing and testing out a ship in his created system.

I played almost constantly, seeing what I could make next, and admiring other peoples' hard and dedicated work as well.  But then, suddenly the game is "released". I was quite shocked, I knew this couldn't be true... the game was a broken mess, did they finally refine the faction and trading system?  Is the combat more fluid and less buggy?  It seems they really haven't.  They left a note at the door. I was devastated, waiting two years in anticipation for all of these features.  I scanned the forums, witnessing developers deleting threads and banning customers asking sincere questions.  It saddens me, and I really thought this game was going to be a success, remembering the hype and positive feedback of the game in its Early Access release.  Hopefully other developers won't follow in their footsteps, but unfortunately it happens frequent enough.  Cheers.

column8:
TL;DR Game is unfinished, developer deletes criticism . Skip this game and spend your money elsewhere.

I bought this game as early access in June of 2013. It had great promise as a kind of single player eve clone. Over the years leading up to my review I've grown rather annoyed and disappointed by this game. You see now in April of 2015 the "tutorial" such as it is remains unfinished, in game help is buggy, there are strange ui issues. I've been waiting to see the developer finish at the basics tutorials, help, ui that works, etc.

You can see other reviews of Kinetic Void with in depth information on what is missing but in the end this game is not finished. Worse yet, the developer asks for input and deletes whole threads where they obtain that requested input and its not the input the developer wanted to hear. Recently the developer admitted that half the team is gone. I am certain the developer will rethink this admission and will delete that comment soon enough.  while not abandoned, the game has little support beyond the developer and two other employees all of which are on a side project.

fine, I don't mind games that are ignored once they are completed but Kinetic void is not completed. Frankly its not even close to completed. Its missing some of the most basic functions and qa rounds any other game gets. 

 I'm glad I only paid us$7 for Kinetic Void, And guess what? I paid too much. Skip this space game and grab any of the other games out there . Preferably something with a bit more polish. 

note to developer to fix this game you need serious help from a paid qa person or two whom you will listen too and fix all the ui bugs. You will need ot add an in game tutorial, in game reference  and some hand holding. You're going to need to stop removing threads that are critical and instead treat them as honest feedback.

column8:
Когда-то давно, может год назад, я купил эту игру, немного поиграл и забросил. Тогда меня неустроил непонятный редактор, непонятно было что делать в плане геймплея. Почему-то я летал очень уныло и орудия не стреляли.

Прошёл год, игра пообновилась, стала более понятной. Стало ясно, пушки не стеляют, если в них не поставить ствол. Редактор кривоватый, но всё же в нём я смог слепить сначала кубик с кабиной, пушкой и движком. Потом файтер на подобии стокового. На момент написания обзора у меня в ангаре в компании находится фрегат, который может надрать корму местным космо-шлюпкам.

Что я считаю плюсом в игре:
+ конструктор, кривой но он есть! И это хорошо!
+ пополняемый контент из Workshop. Иногда попадаются корабли, на которые оформлена подписка. Всёже лучше чем с однообразными стоковыми.
+ выбор рода деятельности - источника дохода. Можешь выполнять миссии, или ковырять астероиды лазером, или спекулировать в торговле, или просто воевать и собирать цветмет с покрасневших космо-шлюпок.
+ детализация кораблей. То есть сегментов кораблей и их большое количество. Есть возможность построить действительно красивый и детализированый корабль.

Что мне ненравится в игре:
- недоработаный геймплей. Если разрабы считают его законченым, то это грустно :( Почему нельзя присоедениться к фракции или создать свою и строить корабли, захватывать станции вместе с солнечными системами, к примеру.
- ограниченное бесконечное пространство. Астероиды луны станции и армада всегда находятся на солнечной стороне планеты. За планетой и в удалении - бесконечная пустота.
- медленный геймплей. Всё вокруг плавает очень медленно. Если разогнаться свыше 2х тысяч, то ещё чувствыется драйв, но на огромных дредноутах которые ползают по 300 скучно.
- ОООООООчень отсталая графика. Спрайты тумана, непонятное мерцание со стороны звезды. небольшая сфера видимости.

Что не могу отнести ни к плюсам ни к минусам:
* ИИ. Он тупой - корабли врезаются в планеты на варпе, врезаются друг в друга в пылу схватки и при загрузке сектора. Но он понимает угрозы - не вступает в бой если не может одолеть, преследует и убегает.
* песочница. Игрок волен как птица. Перед ним не ставится никаких целей, только необязательные миссии.

Итог:
Игра мне лично нравится. Она хорошо убивает время и несмотря на убогую картинку атмосферы радует глаз металлический блеск творения бережно слепленого в ангаре.
Оценка (сугубо личная): 6 из 10.
column9:
A long time ago, maybe a year ago, I bought this game, played it a bit, and then abandoned it. Back then, I was frustrated by the confusing editor; I couldn't figure out what to do with the gameplay. For some reason, flying was incredibly dull and the guns weren't firing.

A year passed, the game was updated, and it became more understandable. It became clear that guns don't fire unless you install a barrel in them. The editor is a bit clunky, but I was still able to cobble together a cube with a cockpit, gun, and engine. Then, a fighter similar to the stock one. At the time of writing, I have a frigate in my hangar that could give the local spaceships a run for their money.

What I consider the game's strengths:
+ The builder, albeit a bit clunky, but it's there! And that's good!
+ Upgradable content from the Workshop. Sometimes you come across ships you've subscribed to. It's still better than the monotonous stock ones.
+ Choice of occupation—a source of income. You can complete missions, or mine asteroids with a laser, or speculate in trade, or simply fight and collect non-ferrous metal from reddened spaceships.
+ Ship detailing. That is, ship segments and a large number of them. It's possible to build a truly beautiful and detailed ship.

What I don't like about the game:
- Underdeveloped gameplay. If the developers consider it finished, that's sad :( Why can't I join a faction or create my own and build ships, capture stations and solar systems, for example?
- Limited, infinite space. Asteroids, stations, and armadas are always on the sunny side of the planet. Beyond the planet and in the distance, there's endless emptiness.
- Slow gameplay. Everything moves very slowly. If you accelerate past 2,000, you can still feel the thrill, but on huge dreadnoughts crawling at 300, it's boring.
- Very, very poor graphics. Fog sprites, strange flickering from the side of a star, small field of view.

What I can't classify as either a pro or a cons:
* AI. It's dumb – ships crash into planets at warp, crash into each other in the heat of battle, and when loading a sector. But it understands threats – it doesn't engage in combat if it can't. Overcome, pursue, and escape.
* Sandbox. The player is as free as a bird. There are no goals, only optional missions.

Summary:
I personally like the game. It's a great time-killer, and despite the poor atmospherics, the metallic sheen of the creation, carefully crafted in the hangar, is pleasing to the eye.
Rating (strictly personal): 6 out of 10.

column8:
Bought this game 2 years ago. Waited for 2 years for a good update. It never came. 

As of 4/18/2015 I just noticed it's now full release with virtually no real updates prior, with a full fledged "Alpha" feel still to the game as a whole. Many things simply don't work. The inventory system, and shipyard is hard to decipher and hard to understand if you aren't delving through piles of old documents about how they work, most of which is out of date to begin with. This wouldn't bother me too much if the game had any depth or solidity to it. Which it doesn't. 

It feels like a skeleton of a game. The bare bones of where a great game would start from into becoming a great game, not where a game ends from as a full release.

column8:
I love the idea. I absolutely adore the intent of the game - its execution is horribly wrong however.

The gameplay has struggled through the Early Acess with odd glitches here and there, and the end result isn't much removed from what it was before release.

The game concept is a rather free-flowing gameplay mechanic to build your own starship, but the game's design is somewhat flawed on both balancing acts of manuverability vs firepower and basic instructions. This takes a whole other level just to explain how to play the game, and to be honest that isn't right for something like this. The basics of the game weapons are Lasers, Cannons and Missiles. Point-defense systems, cargo, salvage and mining are options for a "career" play to build up resources however the grind is long and boring. Ship movement is your typical thrusters and a hyperspace system to jump from point A to B faster, however when jumping you loose your perception on distance and its an annoying wait to see when the ship feels like ending the trip near the target. The shield is a more literal "kinetic field Generator" to protect the ship from damage, but limits movement. You go faster with it off, but take damge to the hull without a shield to cover your rear.

To complicate matters the ship construction designs are done impressively free, able to freely rotate and adjust segments any combination you desire without distance restrictions or locking points - but it comes back to bite the design mechanic in how over-use of too many blocks can kill the gameplay performance. Some moderate limitations have been done to limit weapons and design, but it falls back to an inherit issue with the firepower and accuracy. There is no need for thinking small here, bigger ships, more power, shields and weapons will always do better. It makes any ammount of small craft obsolete and limits the gameplay feel - and punishes you for it as the ship becomes more sluggish with its size increasing. It makes the gameplay drag on in a rather negative way.

I admit its a fun way to loose hours in it, crafting a unique ship - but you'll be so drained when done and after flying it for only short distances you'll not want to actually play with it much after.

The game itself remains largely shallow in its build. No real story, gameplay or function - just create a random set of stars and factions/corporations and choose who you blow up basically. The faction loyalties shift freely with each fight, but it lacks heavily in the substance department for the actual game. No kind of character exists outside nameless portraits and your own nickname. In the basic Career mode you start with a small ship and grind up, but can just kick off in Sandbox to build whatever then just fly faster without the tedious grinding spree to build up to the big ship.

It is a great concept, plenty of heart in it to be honest - but its end application feels lacking, and in a really big way. Pick it up if your really interested in its unique way of doing things, but be wary there isn't much here.

column8:
lächerlich.... langsam fange ich an echte Zweifel an steams Kickstarter Projekt zu bekommen ca. 80-90% ,nach meiner Auffassung, sind für den Mülleimer genau wie dieses Spiel was schon seit ewigkeiten in produktion ist! 
Die Schuld ist gleichmäßig zwischen steam und den Produzenten verteilt da sich beide auf Kosten der menschlichen Neugier bereichern ohne nennenswerte Leistungen zu erbringen. Man gibt Geld aus in der Hoffnung mit etwas Spaß belohnt zu werden welcher zu 85% auf der Strecke bleibt. 
19.99€ für ein Spiel was einfach nur Schrott ist und auch nie über diesen Status hinaus kommen wird!

Fazit:
Mein gesamtbild von steam ist eigentlich positiv aber an Early Aces bzw. Kickstarter kann man sich leicht die Finger verbrennen .... vlt. sollte Steam ne bessere Vorauswahl treffen und nicht jeden Hirnverbrannten mit einer Idee fördern ...
den Kunden und deren Geldbeutel zu liebe
column9:
Ridiculous... I'm slowly starting to have real doubts about Steam's Kickstarter project. In my opinion, about 80-90% are for the trash, just like this game, which has been in production for ages!

The blame is evenly distributed between Steam and the producers, as both enrich themselves at the expense of human curiosity without delivering anything significant. You spend money hoping to be rewarded with some fun, which 85% of the time falls by the wayside.
€19.99 for a game that's simply garbage and will never rise above that status!

Conclusion:
My overall impression of Steam is actually positive, but it's easy to burn your fingers on early aces or Kickstarter.... Maybe Steam should make a better pre-selection and not support every crazy person with an idea...
for the sake of the customers and their wallets

column8:
I bought this game during Early Access because the game looked hugley promising.  This seemed to be the game that would fill the void left in the absence of Elite, Escape Velocity, or a good X game after the abomination that is Rebirth.  Unfortunatley as development trucked along, much more slowly than originally promised at that, features in development began to be cut.  First the scale of the universe was reduced, then the Newtonian physics that were one of the huge selling points of the game were cut in favor of a "simplified" traditional flight model that has ships slow down when engines are cut, turn like atmospheric craft, and have velocity rather than acceleration limits (and these limits are VERY small, measured in triple-diget KPH in the enormity of a solar system).

The robust mission and faction system never materialized, leaving players with very little more to do than in alpha stages.  Basically you can trade legitimatley, or pirate and sale.  The universe offers almost nothing else to do.  There are no indications of where one can buy and sell items let alone how the prices will fluctuate nor what ship modules will be available until you reach a system in the tiny galaxies generated each new time you start a game.  Even then what faction controls a star system (the number of which can be ajusted when you create a galaxy, but they are nothing more than interchangable names and their influence almost never changes for any reason).

The one good thing that I can say about this game is that the ship editor is fairly large.  It was reduced in features since the alpha, again in an attempt to simplify which they failed at anyway, but still offers many options in terms of ship design.  The wide range of vessels both original and copies of famous ships from sci-fi series does attest to this.  Unfortunatley there is nothing to do with your ship other than mindlessly shoot other ships.

If you think that Elite: Dangerous doesn't give you enough help in the universe nor enough interaction with the economy, NPCs, or factions, then stay away from this game.  The tutorials, to the VERY limited extent they exist at all, teach you nothing and somehow saying you recieve no guidence manages to be an understatement.  Even the graphics are nothing to write home about.  Actual old games like X3 or Escape Velocity Nova manage to be better at this, and if you want less story and more trade and exploration with a game that looks beautiful check out Elite: Dangerous or keep your eye out for the (as of time of writing) unreleased Star Citizen or No Man's Sky.

column8: Was I wrong to be under the impression that getting this game on early access came with a price break?  I paid $19.99 for early access and the game is now $19.99 on release?
column9: Was I wrong to be under the impression that getting this game on early access came with a price break?  I paid $19.99 for early access and the game is now $19.99 on release?

column8: I picked this game up again recently, thinking it was still in Pre-alpha phase, but have just now read in another review that it is actually already released as a full game. To put it simply, I noticed no improvements that blew me away enough to even notice that this was the finished game, even after forgetting i owned this game and reinstalling it. I particularly don't like the way the ship-building interface is; it looks cheap and ugly. The game as a whole is difficult for me to play, as the controls seem nearly as ambiguous as what I should even be doing. I don't think I'm a terribly picky person, I understand a game does not need to rely heavily on complex themes or dazzling art styles and graphics to be playable, but this seems to be one of those games where it looks so sloppily put together, that it puts me off from wanting to even humor what gameplay is present. To tie a bow on it, I don't believe this game has any real potential anymore, so i don't recommend that anyone purchase it, and I regret buying it.

column8: This game had a lot of promise originally and then, like a lot of Early Access games, seemed to hit a developmental quagmire. The game went from alpha to finished almost as though it were a spontaneous decision. I don't want to beat a dead horse here and go through a long enumeration of all the things I disliked and liked about the game; on the balance, it's not worth buying.

column8:
Very disappointing.  I bought this back in it's 0.2 or so alpha phase while on sale due to finding the ship building intriguing.  Sadly, that's still the ONLY thing this game is worth anything for.  It shouldn't be released, and the devs should have taken advantage of their eager community.
Don't waste 20 bucks on this.  If it goes on sale for 75%+ off, maybe consider it if you're interested only in ship building and nothing else.
This game had promise, and then they decided to release it as a full game far too early.

column8: Well, I've had the game for a while now and while I would like to say that it was what I had hoped it would be it isn't anywhere near it. When I first started trying out the game I instantly hit a roadblock of "what are the controls?". There wasn't much in the way of tutorials and what I did find only helped me to get through the ship building phase. After that I couldn't really do much except for maybe make the ship move forward, at least I think it was going forward. To be honest I just quit playing it because I was hoping that the game would get the needed imnprovements since it was still in early access at that point. I have waited until now and it doesn't really look like much progress has occured and the game is no longer marked as ealy access. While I do get that stuff happens, I feel like this was an over ambitious project that is a bit of a dissapointment with the results. While I can still hope that the devs get it completed and functioning as advertised, I don't see it happening any time soon. I feel that this game might as well be considered dead unless it can get a big revival in the developement.

column8: This game is not finished. If it were finished it has the potential to be awesome. It should still be in early access.
column9: This game is not finished. If it were finished it has the potential to be awesome. It should still be in early access.

column8:
This is the very first Steam product that made me write a review. And a [b]very[/b] negative one. The reason is that, apparently, if you don't write a review for Kinetic Void on Steam, your opinion about this game doesn't count. The developer Sean Pollman a.k.a. LumberingTroll ([i]now that I think about the names connected to KV – Lumbering[b]TROLL[/b], Kinetic [b]VOID[/b], [b]BAD[/b]land Studio – in the retrospect, I think those should have been blatant warning signs in themselves, maybe the stupider of us just didn't get the message :-D[/i]) said that "KV has sold 120,000 copies and only 351 people gave it a thumbs down [which is the number of negative Steam reviews to the date of posting his statement]". Yes, unbelievable as it may seem, this is actually the mindset of the developer. But that's only the very start.

Kinetic Void is a "game" (I am very reluctant to call KV in its current state a game, but I'll get to that in time) that had spent three years in development. Unfortunately, the state in which the "game" happens to be now doesn't reflect it a least bit. From very basic, spartan, ugly and sometimes non-functional UI, to a very poor amount of content in the game (there's really just nothing to do beyond the ship builder). The optimization also is a joke, graphics are so last-century, yet you need a decent rig to run it fluently ([i]X3: Albion Prelude, despite being older game, looks much better and runs far smoother, especially on my former GPU NVidia 9600 GT, on which X3:AP ran smooth as silk, whereas KV lagged like hell all the time; but to be fair, I have to admit that on Radeon HD 7850 I have no problem with either game, so it's especially older computers that will have a problem with running KV[/i]). 

The "game" is simply far from being finished. [b]Everywhere you look, every aspect of the "game" that you examine, everything just feels unpolished or downright unfinished.[/b] Also, the only part of the "game" which you can actually enjoy is the ship builder which is the most finished feature of the game (by the standards of KV, because it's still lacking in many ways). The rest is just flying in empty space (you can also enter the atmosphere of any planet, only to be presented with a close-up sight of bland atrocious-resolution textures), shooting at enemy ships and mining (consisting of concentrating your mining beam on an asteroid for dulling amount of time). And that's about it. 
Already dissuaded from buying Kinetic Void? Just wait please, we still haven't even left the starting line...

Three years of development after which Kinetic Void left Early Access program and was labeled a "finished" product (despite still being in the same unfinished state as it'd been always before). That was in November 2014. Now it's almost April 2015 and no progress whatsoever has been made to make the "game" actually working or to expand its direly lacking features. Only a few patches with no actual improvements, save for some bugfixes, came out since that time. Just take a look at the patch announcement history. 
"[i]But wait, the developers just have a lot on their plate right now and maybe they get to it later and right the respective wrongs[/i]," you may say. Now, bear in mind that Sean Pollman said himself on the forums that his team has dissolved, and that they're now down to only two people "working" on the "game" (you have to take this in with a very open mind, since that "work" is nowhere to be seen on the "game") and that they've also opened a brick & mortar board-game store, plus they've started working on "another small project" to cover their costs. 
[b]Yes, two people are working on Kinetic Void, manning their store and then even working on another "small project", all at the same time.[/b] Go figure how long will it take to shape Kinetic Void into anything resembling a "working state" (also bear in mind that to get in its current sorry and unfinished state, it took three years for KV, and that's with more people working on it full-time). I'd wager that it'll take forever and then some, but I'm open to bets.

Based on all the mentioned, it's no wonder that negative reviews started rolling in after the "game" was made "final" in November last year. I had bought Kinetic Void literally week earlier and expected it to stay in the Early Access for some time, since I knew that I was buying an unfinished product at the time (with a very naive hope that I would get an actual finished game someday – [b]I thereby openly admit, that I was very stupid to buy it :-)[/b]). When the "release" came week later, I was quite (negatively) surprised by that but I decided to wait a few months to see how the things would unveil. 
We already know how it all actually went, so it's no wonder that I started getting pissed off, along with many other former fans of the "game". So, after a developer posted his excuses on the forum, I endeavoured to reply (very honestly, but hopefully not rudely – [url=http://imgur.com/3LDVYfi]I'll let you be the judges[/url]). But boy, have I dared too much by that! Some other people came with their opinions after me, the developer came with his disrespectful retort (check out the [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/MandrakeTheBard/recommended/227160/]review by Mandrake[/url], he's among the ones who had been discussing in this thread) and not a very long time after, the whole thread suddenly disappeared. I don't know if it was deleted by Pollman or Valve (some folks wrote that they reported the thread on the grounds of the developer's disrespectful reactions), but it was. So yeah, I hope you get the picture of how you're treated when you express your dissatisfaction with Kinetic Void or the manners of its developer.

[b]To sum it all up: if you want to support one individual by the name Sean Pollman who in three years isn't capable enough to develop even so much as a basic game that just works (despite his promises), doesn't respect his paying customers, takes their money to open his board-game store and then calls them (unpleasant) names for expressing their opinions, then by all means, go ahead and buy this "game". 

If you actually value your hard-earned money, then I recommend to stay away from this inept developer and his atrocious product as far as you only can. Get yourself X3: Terran Conflict + Albion Prelude instead, which comes for the exact same price, yet it is a far, far, FAR better product in EVERY regard.[/b]

column8:
DEVELOPER NOPE - Try the X series instead (minus Rebirth).

[b]TL;DR version:  This is a case where the developer literally took the money, padded their Steam library full of games to work hard on "developing" and then after the rest of the team QUIT the lead developer used the remaining money to start up a physical game store in a mall while [u]LYING[/u] to those who bought KV that there was no more money for development - check the bottom image for a good list of why this game's development died to be Spacebased from Early Access.[/b]

Somehow, my hours played got reset despite checking the game out when it had promise (I actually had to boot it again and checked out the minor additions since this title was given the "Spacebase 1.0 Treatment".  It was obviously pushed out too early considering part of the "finished game" has "(Not currently implemented)" placeholders.  Development was chugging along, albeit slow, but most folks knew that when they were getting into the game...and could forgive that easily.

The main problem isn't the gameplay to be found in the game, as it has a decent foundation with a ship builder and more (almost like a 3D Drox Operative)...but outside of that, there really isn't much to the game still, and unfortunately due to developer meltdown there probably never will be. 

This is another Early Access dud where they slap a 1.0 on it (to cash in on the sales that might generate...which it did not), expect the community to finish it, then spend time making excuses about how Steam wouldn't allow them to put it back into the Early Access program while lashing out at their customers for not crowdfunding someone's dream and being happy about the results when it was prematurely released with poor communication surrounding it.

That is exactly what LumberingTroll (developer) did, and when people pointed this out in a thread asking if the game was still being developed - after the dev wasn't communicating with the community shortly after the "Spacebase Treatment" of slapping a 1.0 on a title then bailing to start up a physical game store without letting those following the game know what was going on in dev plans - LumberingTroll called everyone "retarded" and then deleted the thread when it appeared that he might have to face responsibility for his own actions.

Yes, apparently game developers - the REAL Steam customers while everyone else is supposed to be happy with poor faith business practices - are allowed to break the Steam posting rules whenever they feel like it and can only be held "responsible" by deleting the incriminating evidence from the virtual sandbox Steam gives them to do whatever to the "lesser customers" - also known as "marks" - only when it embarrasses them.

The problem with that is that people were otherwise mostly forgiving up until the "Spacebase Treatment" and the childish forum whitewashing.

You thought you had a problem with "bad reviews" before, LumberingTroll?

You just gave people reason to write more.

Maybe next time you'll bother to treat your customers in the same respect you wish to be treated, but until this developer does some serious reparations I would suggest to avoid the developer's dysfunction at all possibilities.  Those antics changed my position from a silent "wouldn't recommend until it becomes more complete" to a "until this developer removes their head from their backside, continuing to pay attention to them might in itself deserve a refund".

LumberingTroll:
"You are all being ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and this is why most developers refuse to reply on forums. 

KV was released early, yep, nothing new ive said that before. Valve wont let me put it back in early access so there is nothing I can do about that. KV isn't generating money, I cant put funds into its development right now, I work on it when I can in my spare time. I am hoping we (the two people still at the company) can put out a small project to generate some revenue to fund development. Like it or not the game is as it is for now. I'm sorry some of you feel your $5 - $20 was wasted. If you guys dont want to be civil I'll gladly just avoid the forums from now on like most developers do."

Blame the customer?  The customer writes reviews to that effect.

Edit 26 Apr 15:  
Screenshot of developer banning someone for reporting the developer's comment for being in violation of the Steam Rules:  http://imgur.com/nyzSXdj

Screenshot of developer asking for feedback about why customer reviews were so negative: http://i.imgur.com/EmJ9cPV.png

Someone gives the developer this info (long after the dev bailed from the title except for excuses), to which the developer disagreed enough that they deleted the entire thread:
http://i.imgur.com/8vcRzdl.png

Edit 30 Nov 15:  
LT continues his practise of whitewashing the forum of his misdeeds, namely running off to go start a physical game store after expanding his game library and his own KS backings substantially a bit after the Kickstarter, while those who point this out whenever LT plays up the "barely able to scrape by starving developer" farce get permabanned and purged from the forums:
http://imgur.com/0P092rk

Here is an article describing where the remaining funds for developing KV went to:
http://www.argusleader.com/story/news/business-journal/2015/08/11/badland-games-caters-board-game-players/31505761/

column8:
On a mission to review every game in my library and I'm sad to say that I don't know what to say about this game.....

It's shipbuilding is fun and complex, takes a bit of learning, but worth it.  

The game itself is rather lacking though.  I feel that it would have benefited a LOT from multiplayer, if nothing else just to fly around and show off your awesome designs and see other player's awesome designs.   Maybe destroy other player's awesome designs.  Sadly, that never happened.

To be fair, it's been a while since I've played this game and before writing this review I thought to myself "Maybe I should go play it a bit" ..... but I just couldn't bring myself to do it.  I think this is a good example of what you get when you say a game has "potential," it's a risk you just have to take.

The game itself is rather lacking though.  I feel that it would have benefited a LOT from multiplayer, if nothing else just to fly around and show off your awesome designs and see other player's awesome designs.   Maybe destroy other player's awesome designs.  Sadly, that never happened.

To be fair, it's been a while since I've played this game and before writing this review I thought to myself "Maybe I should go play it a bit" ..... but I just couldn't bring myself to do it.  I think this is a good example of what you get when you say a game has "potential," it's a risk you just have to take.

column8:
I don't like this game at all.

First of all, as shown by EVE online, the idea itself is good, but the way it was put into the game is awful. The editor is quite good, I admit, but the game substantially lacks gameplay and puts a strain on my I5 + Nvidia GTX 680MX + 8 GB RAM system.

If it was improved in the future, It'd be good. Otherwise, it's a waste of money. I've bought 30 games on steam and this is the only one I regret.

column8:
I was really excited about the game when Purchased it the game was still in early release and had its flaws, but as time went on the flaws were never fixed. The ship builder is pretty cool but its hard to figure out how everything works (not everything does). Then when you actualy build a ship that works there really isnt a point other than flying around. The game offers no direction which isnt a bad thing (space engineers) but the sandbox feel is lost after building your ship. Trading is difficult to understand and resource gathering is bugged. 

As of now 3/15 the game lacks a sense of purpose for the player. Why should I mine? Why should I gather salvage? Why should I fight these pirates (other than its the part of the game that works the best).

If your looking for a game with no real goal and no reason to play any farther than building a ship and shooting something this game is for you. BUT if you want a game that actualy has play value and will keep you envolved for more than 4 hours look elsewear. THIS IS NOT A SANDBOX GAME. ITS NOT EVEN A SPACE ADVENTURE GAME. THE ONLY TAG THEY GOT RIGHT IS SIMULATION AND THAT ISNT EVEN 100% CORRECT

column8:
Kinetic Void легче рассматривать как две игры в одной: конструктор кораблей и космическую "песочницу".

Первая - представляет собой замысловатый 3D редактор кораблей, снабжённый довольно скучным и дотошным обучением. Быстро построить "хоть что-то" и взлететь не получится, но любители поковыряться в настройках и узлах могут создать корабль по своему вкусу.  Игроку доступно несколько десятков готовых модулей в 5 размерах, которые можно без ограничений вращать, стыковать и раскрашивать. Особых требований к конструкции нет - лишь бы была кабина, хотя бы один корпус и двигатель, а также пара-тройка внутренних подсистем. Одним словом, в Steam Workshop настоящее раздолье: тут есть "Тысячелетний Сокол" и имперский "Звёздный разрушитель" из "Звёздных войн", знаменитый корабль из сериала "Светлячок", "Kestrel" из FTL.

А вот вторая половина удалась куда хуже. Так называемая "песочница" выглядит как неумелая калька с EVE Online, даже выбор целей и контекстное меню схожи. Даром, что кораблём можно управлять с клавиатуры - эффективно передвигаться тут можно исключительно в "варп бабле". Даже интерфейс в какой-то мере похож на исландскую ММО.

Однако, главная проблема Kinetic Void - абсолютно пустой мир, в котором нечего делать. И хотя карта каждый раз создаётся случайным образом, тут каждый раз одинаково скучно. Миссии, "фарм" репуации с фракциями, добыча минералов, торговля... Всё сделано настолько топорно и бездушно, что это усыпляет лучше любого снотворного.
column9:
Kinetic Void is best thought of as two games in one: a ship builder and a space sandbox.

The first is a complex 3D ship editor, complete with a rather tedious and meticulous tutorial. You won't be able to quickly build "anything" and take off, but those who enjoy tinkering with the settings and components can create a ship to their liking. Players have access to several dozen pre-made modules in five sizes, which can be freely rotated, joined, and painted. There are no specific design requirements – just a cockpit, at least one hull and engine, and a couple of internal subsystems. In short, Steam Workshop is a real treat: there's the Millennium Falcon and the Imperial Star Destroyer from Star Wars, the famous ship from Firefly, and the Kestrel from FTL.

The second half, however, is far less successful. The so-called "sandbox" feels like a crude rip-off of EVE Online; even the target selection and context menu are similar. Although you can control your ship with the keyboard, effective navigation is only possible in the warp bubble. Even the interface is somewhat reminiscent of an Icelandic MMO.

However, Kinetic Void's main problem is its completely empty world, with nothing to do. And although the map is randomly generated each time, it's equally boring. Missions, reputation farming with factions, mineral mining, trading... Everything is so crude and soulless that it's more numbing than any sleeping pill.

column8:
Highly incomplete game, the controls don't make sense. It crashes, and it has no real tutorial. It has info popups, but alot of them aren't helpful and the ones that might be are hard to understand without a firm grasp on another mechanic that wasn't explained.

There seems to be no real missions or campaign, there's nothing to really do as far as I can tell. It has screenshots of cool things on the steam page, but I just can't manage to get out of making my first ship and not dying to the randomly generated bandits that kill me before the environment fully loads.

This game is broken, buggy, and content incomplete. They said it was released because they couldn't be arsed to finish it. A true exploitation of early access, considering they haven't really done much since it was first realeased on steam.

Also, for those talking about ths ship builder being the best part of the game... Space Engineers has far better ship building that is easier to understand, and Space Engineers has a little something to do with the ships. This game has nothing to do once you make a ship.

column8:
THE ZOOM SPEED IN THE BUILD-A-SHIP SECTION IS UNBEARABLE!!!!!!!!!! It takes waaaaaay to long to zoom out/in to your ship in the construction menu, and the UI is horrific. Badly organised and ill explained jumble of icons that mean nothing to me. This could be so much better if these things were improved upon. The old UI in the early days of the game was VASTLY superior. It was better organised, more consise and easy to navigate. The older ship-builder was better too, now there is too much fiddling and clicking everywhere. The old one was click and place. not click and click again, and then learning you have placed it wrong so you have to remove it and then click then click again. 

It is such a shame, because this game is a great idea that feels as if it has been rushed. even the main gameplay is dull. Just don't bother throwing money at it, you'll find better uses of it elsewhere, preferably anything other than this heap of junk.

*(as in: you browse the internet for cool looking ships other people have made and then download them)
Controls are pretty basic and easy to pick up and the graphics look nice, except the "Space" is just a huge colorful cloud, instead of a starry sky.

column8:
Just what the hell happened?

There was so much going for this game. The very thought of building your own ship from different parts and explore a galaxy was the major reason i bought this game when it was first released in alpha. 

I did stop playing every now and then because the ship building system was just fucked up, and updates and fixes are barely there if at all. 

The huge amount of wait between updates and lack of help made me quit then months done the road i reinstalled it noticing that it was "Fulling Released" started it up and what do i see? 

JACK SHIT! 

It feels like nothings been done and Badland Studio just decided to slap the "Full Release" Sticker on it because they too where done with it. 

Such a damn waste of an idea

column8:
The ship designer is cool.
But it's the only thing about the game that could be called complete and efficient.
Not only was the gameplay so poor that I couldn't even bring myself to play more than an hour outside the ship editor, whoever was behind this game forgot to finish the graphics engine.
I don't even know how you miss that, forgetting to finish the graphics engine shows itself with spontaneous blooms of light filling the screen, weird looking planets (Their textures do not increase in detail with proximity, and they lack atmospheric effects for colour emissions) and very poor performance (Runs fine at full settings on my computer, but considering how dull the graphics are at max settings, that's no excuse for it to be generating a lot of heat or be unplayable with my old graphics card).

column8:
I bought into this game early on, and to be honest i'm seeing very little change since then.
A very ambitious title poorly executed.
If you manage to build a flyable ship and leave the station you will be at first underwhelmed, by the low res graphics and lazily rendered space station. You will then be overwhelmed as you try to figure out just what it is you're supposed to do.
There's no story arc, just supposedly ramdomly generated missions, (of which i never found).
I understand the dev team was small, but that is no excuse.
Anather 6 - 12 months would have seen a greatly improved, and realized game.
Thanks Badland.
DO NOT BUY
column9:
I bought into this game early on, and to be honest i'm seeing very little change since then.
A very ambitious title poorly executed.
If you manage to build a flyable ship and leave the station you will be at first underwhelmed, by the low res graphics and lazily rendered space station. You will then be overwhelmed as you try to figure out just what it is you're supposed to do.
There's no story arc, just supposedly ramdomly generated missions, (of which i never found).
I understand the dev team was small, but that is no excuse.
Anather 6 - 12 months would have seen a greatly improved, and realized game.
Thanks Badland.
DO NOT BUY

column8: А на выходе пустой пшик... Разработчики обещали многое, но в итоге доделали до более менее внятного состояния только редактор строительства кораблей. Сама игра полная пустышка. Моя оценка - 2/10
column9: The result is a complete dud... The developers promised a lot, but in the end, only the shipbuilding editor was able to achieve a more or less coherent state. The game itself is a complete dud. My rating: 2/10

column8:
(Wichtiges Update weiter unten!!! 15.12.2015) + (Einsicht eines ehemaligen Mitarbeiters Irgendwann 2021 oder so)

Das einzige was KV wirklich gut macht ist der Part mit dem man sich Schiffe aus vorgefertigten Teilen bauen kann. Die Möglichkeiten sind hier enorm hoch und die Community ist sehr kreativ. Das war es dann auch. Was hier am Sandkasten Prinzip angepriesen wird ist im Grunde sehr eingeschränkt. Wenn das eigene Schiff fertig ist darf man versuchen damit herumzufliegen, Missionen bestreiten (flieg-dahin-töte-alles-komm-zurück) oder Bergabau an Asteroiden durchführen. 

Die Steuerung ist äußerst unintuitiv und das Interface grausam unübersichtlich. Vorallem beim Verkauf von Waren in Stationen fällt dies auf. Die Community hat seit geraumer Zeit auf Tutorials gehofft, diese sind aber selbst nach Release (!) nur in Textform enthalten. Missionen funktionieren nur bedingt (verbuggt) und versprochener Missionseditor ist immer noch nicht im Spiel implementiert. Fraktionen sind vorhanden und haben eine Freund/Feind einstellung gegenüber dem Spieler, allerdings verlassen sie nie ihr Territorium um zB. gegen Nachbarn Krieg zu führen (also keine großen Massenschlachten, alles eher statisch). 

Version 1.0 kam für alle sehr überraschend, da das Spiel noch lange nicht fertig war. Dies wurde in den Foren auch mehrfach diskutiert und letztendlich von den Entwicklern geblockt.

http://steamcommunity.com/app/227160/discussions/0/627456486573555094/

http://steamcommunity.com/app/227160/discussions/0/620703493315704463/

http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198035632014/recommended/227160 (geblocktes Review)

Natürlich ist der Tonfall nicht immer sauber und es ist verständlich das man empfindlich reagiert wenn es das eigene Produkt geht, aber Kritik wird generell schnell unterbunden. 

Anhand der schlechten Rezensionen fragen mittlerweile die Entwickler was für Verbesserungen die Spieler an KV vorschlagen. Dies bleibt aber nur im Rahmen was schon existiert, d.h. also keine neuen Inhalte. 

Was mir persönlich gegen den Strich geht, ist nicht das Inhaltslose Spiel, sondern die Tatsache das KV auf Kickstarter erfolgreich war und das sie zusätzlich auf den Early Access Zug von Steam mit aufgesprungen sind. Dennoch scheinen sie nicht genug Mittel (oder Willen) zu haben aus KV ein richtiges Spiel zu programmieren. Sie beteuern zwar immer wieder das sie es weiter unterstützen, aber anhand der nach dem Release veröffentlichten Patches kann man sehen das da nur Bugbereinigung kommt.


!!! Update !!! (18.03.2015): 
Seit Januar war es etwas still in um Kinetic Void und die Leute haben nun schon diskutiert ob das Spiel "verlassen" wurde, da zeitgleich ein Brettspielladen unter selben Logo und Namen der Entwickler in der "stillen Zeit" gegründet wurde. https://www.facebook.com/BadlandGaming?ref=ts&fref=ts

Der Thread der zur Erklärung des Ganzen dienen sollte wurde nun leider gelöscht. Als der Entwickler etwas ausfallend wurde, hat ihn der Steamuser Starbug wegen Beleidigung gemeldet und wurde dafür aus den KV Foren gebannt.

Hier ein Bildnachweis des Posts des Enwicklers (LumberingTroll) vom genannten User:
" http://imgur.com/nyzSXdj

Message is quoted as reported. I was banned for reporting him"

Die Herzen bedeuten "r e t a r d e d"

Zusammenfassung des Statements zur momentanen Situation in KV:
-> 2 Leute haben das Entwicklerteam verlassen
-> die 2 verbleibenden Entwickler arbeiten (simultan?) an einem anderen Projekt, die gemischten Userwertungen führen zu geringen Verkäufen = wenig Geld für KV für so "viele" entwickler
-> Steam lässt diesen Titel nicht wieder (!) ins Early Access Programm rein
-> der Brettspieleladen soll das Budget aufstocken und das leere Büro füllen
-> KV wird nicht aufgegeben - dennoch keine neuen Features da ja alles schon im Spiel enthalten ist was versprochen wurde - doch die Entwicklung wird sich stark verlangsamen
-> das Bewertungssystem bei Steam ist so nicht in Ordnung, da Leute bei einer Durschnittswertung von "Gemischt oder mixed" das Spiel nicht kaufen würden (überraschung!)
-> alles wird noch mal relativiert das man selbst Schuld sei dieses Spiel gekauft zu haben, man hätte ja wissen können das so ein kleines Entwicklerteam nicht solchen Anforderungen (der Spieler)  gerecht werden könne

Wer gerne etwas tiefer in die Materie gehen will, sollte sich dieses Review samt Kommentaren (Englisch) zu gemüte führen. Es zeigt deutliche Hinweise das Geld nicht nur in die Entwicklung von KV hineingeflossen ist sondern für private Zwecke genutzt wurde:

http://steamcommunity.com/id/lOriginalR/recommended/227160/

Wie es scheint hat der User (Entwickler) LumberingTroll nach der Kickstarter Kampagne von Kinetic Void kontinuierlich seine Steam Bibliothek mit "triple a" Titeln jeweils zum Vollpreis (also zum Release) gefüllt und selbst auf Kickstarter 141 Brettspiele (!) unterstützt. Anhand der Kickstarter Kommentare lässt sich feststellen, dass er nicht nur zwei oder drei Dollar, sondern so viel investiert hat, dass er das jeweilige Brettspiel auch zugeschickt bekommt. D.h. pro Brettspiel kann man mindestens (meist noch mehr das es ja kein digitales Gut ist) 20-25 $ zählen.

Steamprofil: http://steamcommunity.com/id/LumberingTroll
Kickstarterprofil: https://www.kickstarter.com/profile/seanpollman

Gleichzeitig beschwert er sich nun das er ein armer Entwickler sei der momentan kein Geld in KV investieren kann.


!!! Update 2 !!! (15.12.2015): Der Entwickler sucht in dem Steam Forum nach neuen Mitarbeitern 

http://steamcommunity.com/app/227160/discussions/0/541907867779253146/

Viel mehr passiert hier auch nicht. Der Entwickler meldet sich nur wenn es wirklich wichtig ist oder der Eindruck entstehen könne niemand lese das Forum. Mittlerweile ist nur noch das Forum "Fragen" für die Außenwelt sichtbar, nur die Leute die das Spiel auch besitzen haben den kompletten Zugriff.

http://steamcommunity.com/app/227160/discussions/1/537405286649714540/#c458604254434100892

Hier steht es offiziell: Da er LumberingTroll keine Ahnung vom Programmieren hat, steht KV erst mal auf Eis. Modsupport wird nicht kommen da schlicht das Wissen dafür fehlt. Da dieses "Spiel" anscheinend immer noch ein wenig Geld einbringt wird es auch keine opensource unterstützung geben.


Seit 2 Jahren keine Updates (weder contentupdates noch bugfixes). Wer sich dieses Spiel kauft ist selber Schuld, denn das rechtfertigt nicht einmal dieser halbe "shipbuilder". Jeder der dieses Spiel nun kauft, unterstützt nur den Brettspieleladen des Entwicklers und ich garantiere das sich hier nichts mehr tun wird.


Leider sprengt der Kommentar das Zeichenlimit für dieses Kackspiel. Im Kommentarbereich noch eine Einsicht eines ehemaligen Mitarbeiters.





//////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
Kurzfassung: Schaut euch die Screenshots und Artworks an und ihr kennt 98% des Spiels -> Bau ein Schiff und führe das in einem leeren, großen und langweiligen Raum gassi. Die Ausrede mimimi es ist doch Alpha zieht nicht mehr. Da nun auch seitens der Entwickler keine Kommunikation mehr erfolgt, ist meine Hoffnung nun endgültig gestorben das aus diesem "Ship-building simulator" noch was brauchbares wird. Zudem ist das soziale Verhalten des Entwicklers unter aller Sau. Leider scheint es auch so als wäre ein Teil des Kickstarter/Steam Geldes nicht ins Spiel sondern in einen Brettspieleladen investiert worden. Der übrigens pleite ging.


Kinetic Void

Name ist hier Programm.
column9:
(Important update below!!! December 15, 2015) + (Insight from a former employee Sometime in 2021 or so)

The only thing KV really does well is the part where you can build ships from prefabricated parts. The possibilities are enormous, and the community is very creative. That's it. What's being touted here in terms of the sandbox principle is essentially very limited. Once your ship is finished, you can try flying around with it, completing missions (fly there, kill everything, come back), or mining asteroids.

The controls are extremely unintuitive, and the interface is terribly confusing. This is especially noticeable when selling goods in stations. The community has been hoping for tutorials for some time, but even after release (!), they are only available in text form. Missions only work partially (buggy), and the promised mission editor is still not implemented in the game. Factions exist and have a friend/enemy stance toward the player, but they never leave their territory to wage war against neighbors, for example (so no large-scale battles; everything is rather static).

Version 1.0 came as a big surprise to everyone, as the game was far from finished. This was discussed several times in the forums and ultimately blocked by the developers.

http://steamcommunity.com/app/227160/discussions/0/627456486573555094/

http://steamcommunity.com/app/227160/discussions/0/620703493315704463/

http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198035632014/recommended/227160 (blocked review)

Of course, the tone isn't always clean, and it's understandable that people react sensitively when it comes to their own product, but criticism is generally quickly suppressed.

Based on the negative reviews, the developers are now asking players what improvements they're suggesting for KV. However, this only remains within the scope of what already exists, meaning no new content.

What personally bothers me isn't the lack of content, but the fact that KV was successful on Kickstarter and that they also jumped on Steam's Early Access bandwagon. Nevertheless, they don't seem to have enough resources (or will) to develop KV into a proper game. They repeatedly claim to continue supporting it, but based on the patches released after the release, it's clear that only bug fixes are being released.

!!! Update!!! (March 18, 2015):
Since January, things have been a bit quiet around Kinetic Void, and people have already started discussing whether the game has been "abandoned," since a board game store with the same logo and developer name was founded during the "quiet period." https://www.facebook.com/BadlandGaming?ref=ts&fref=ts

The thread intended to explain this has unfortunately been deleted. When the developer became somewhat abusive, Steam user Starbug reported him for insulting him and was subsequently banned from the KV forums.

Here is an image credit from the developer's (LumberingTroll) post by the user mentioned:
" http://imgur.com/nyzSXdj

Message is quoted as reported. I was banned for reporting him"

The hearts mean "retarded"

Summary of the statement on the current situation in KV:
-> 2 people have left the development team
-> The 2 remaining developers are working (simultaneously?) on another project, the mixed user ratings lead to low sales = little money for KV for so "many" developers
-> Steam will not allow this title back (!) into the Early Access program
-> The board game store should increase the budget and fill the empty office
-> KV will not be abandoned - but there will be no new features since everything promised is already included in the game - but development will slow down significantly
-> The rating system on Steam is not correct, as people with an average rating of "Mixed" or mixed" wouldn't buy the game (surprise!)
-> everything is put into perspective by saying that it's their own fault for buying this game; they should have known that such a small development team couldn't meet such demands (of the players).

If you'd like to delve a little deeper, you should read this review and comments (in English). It shows clear indications that the money wasn't just invested in the development of KV, but was also used for private purposes:

http://steamcommunity.com/id/lOriginalR/recommended/227160/

It seems that after the Kinetic Void Kickstarter campaign, the user (developer) LumberingTroll continuously filled his Steam library with "triple-A" titles, each at full price (i.e., at release), and even backed 141 board games (!) on Kickstarter. Based on the Kickstarter comments, it's clear that he invested not just two or three dollars, but so much that he even received the respective board games. This means you can expect at least $20-25 per board game (usually more since it's not a digital product).

Steam profile: http://steamcommunity.com/id/LumberingTroll
Kickstarter profile: https://www.kickstarter.com/profile/seanpollman

At the same time, he's now complaining that he's a poor developer who can't currently invest any money in KV.

!!! Update 2!!! (12/15/2015): The developer is looking for new employees in the Steam forum.

http://steamcommunity.com/app/227160/discussions/0/541907867779253146/

Not much else is happening here. The developer only posts when it's really important or when the impression might arise that no one reads the forum. Now, only the "Questions" forum is visible to the outside world, and only people who actually own the game have full access.

http://steamcommunity.com/app/227160/discussions/1/537405286649714540/#c458604254434100892

Here's the official information: Since LumberingTroll has no clue about programming, KV is on hold for the time being. Mod support will not be forthcoming due to a lack of knowledge. Since this "game" apparently still makes a little money, there will be no open source support either.

No updates (neither content updates nor bug fixes) for two years. Anyone who buys this game has only themselves to blame, because not even this half-baked "shipbuilder" justifies it. Anyone who buys this game now is only supporting the developer's board game store, and I guarantee that nothing more will happen here.

Unfortunately, this comment exceeds the character limit for this crappy game. In the comments section, you'll find some insight from a former employee.

/////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
Summary: Look at the screenshots and artwork and you'll know 98% of the game -> Build a ship and drive it around an empty, large, and boring room. The "whine it's alpha" excuse doesn't work anymore. Since there's no more communication from the developers, my hope that this "ship-building simulator" will ever become anything useful has finally died. Furthermore, the developer's social media presence is abysmal. Unfortunately, it also seems as if part of the Kickstarter/Steam money wasn't invested in the game, but in a board game store. Which, by the way, went bankrupt.

Kinetic Void

The name says it all.

This is a great game. and very nice looking graphics. With it being in early access it is constantly under development. And is updated often. If you like building ships from parts instead of from scratch block by block this is the game for you. If you want another Space engineers. This is not it. Well worth the purchase.

column8:
I bought and backed this game 2 years ago, when it was in fledgling alpha state. My first Early-release, too.

I was an active part of the community at the time, doing screenshots and showing off ships, complementing eachothers' ships, writing guides, giving feedback to the developers.

6 months later I grew tired of the slow updating (as well as the game) so I stopped playing it as actively as I once was. 3 months after that I stopped completely.

I patiently waited for new updates that came once per 3-4 months at a time sometimes, and briefly brought myself to speed with how things were.

Then they began to rush the release. I could tell because they suddenly sped up the alpha states faster than the content actually generated. From .022 to a .#, and then to simply d.#, like they were trying to rename the process to give the illusion of progress. Then the release came. I, like many other backers, was immensly disapointed with the game.

While real progress was made in these 2 years, the progress could have easily fit into one year. 

Don't get me wrong, the shipbuilder is GREAT. Or, at least last time I checked.

But then you're in space. It can get really laggy, and there isn't much to do. I don't mind having all the lore of the universe in your head, but developers promised economy systems, intricate faction mechanics, ect. Nothing is intricate.

Even if this was still in alpha I would give a shaky reccomendation at best. Progress was slow, but continuing.

But this 'release' gives me the feeling that this game is rather a let-down.

Sorry, but I'm disappointed.

column8:
It took me several hours and several visits to the forums to unravel Kinetic Void.  Once I deciphered it I saw enough promise in the idea to purchase a second copy for a friend.

The game was flawed but it was Early Access. Lots of things didn't work as expected.  Some things didn't work at all.  There was little correspondence between the sparse documentation and game play.   I put the game's developement somewhere between late Alpha and early Beta.  

Then, almost without warning, Kinetic Void went to full release.  The broken parts were still broken.  The unfinished parts were still unfinished.  The devs claimed they had delivered what they had promised but that they would clean up the remaining rough edges.

Several months  later the edges are still as rough as they were at _release_.

Ship building works well enough but there is a lack of detail.  All components engines, turrets, hull, weapons have a generic, unfinished feel.  The mission system doesn't work but combat mostly does work.  Trade & inventory management are overly complex and nearly indecipherable.   Movement & control work but the interface is inconsistent.

The Devs are a small team.  Apparently there are only three of them yet theyconsistently  have ignored offers of help from the community.

Perhaps it's project burn-out.  Perhaps the devs will find a second wind and, with a mighty effort,  put a playable game together.  I wouldn't count on it.

Put your money somewhere else.

Two sad thumbs down.
column9:
It took me several hours and several visits to the forums to unravel Kinetic Void.  Once I deciphered it I saw enough promise in the idea to purchase a second copy for a friend.

The game was flawed but it was Early Access. Lots of things didn't work as expected.  Some things didn't work at all.  There was little correspondence between the sparse documentation and game play.   I put the game's developement somewhere between late Alpha and early Beta.  

Then, almost without warning, Kinetic Void went to full release.  The broken parts were still broken.  The unfinished parts were still unfinished.  The devs claimed they had delivered what they had promised but that they would clean up the remaining rough edges.

Several months  later the edges are still as rough as they were at _release_.

Ship building works well enough but there is a lack of detail.  All components engines, turrets, hull, weapons have a generic, unfinished feel.  The mission system doesn't work but combat mostly does work.  Trade & inventory management are overly complex and nearly indecipherable.   Movement & control work but the interface is inconsistent.

The Devs are a small team.  Apparently there are only three of them yet theyconsistently  have ignored offers of help from the community.

Perhaps it's project burn-out.  Perhaps the devs will find a second wind and, with a mighty effort,  put a playable game together.  I wouldn't count on it.

Put your money somewhere else.

Two sad thumbs down.

column8:
(I played in offline mode for ~3 hours that weren't logged)

This game just isn't finished. It has promise, but it just isn't delivering on the promise.

It has a tutorial of similar scope and depth to the original Kerbal Space Program tutorial on rocketry, but nothing at all for what you're supposed to do after you leave the space station!

Missions pop up in the dialog box but they don't tell you where to go or who to fight, just "We need help over here"

Trying to figure out how to get from one side of a system to another is almost impossible and relies largely on blind luck to figure it out, and once you do figure that out and who exactly is calling for your help, good luck ever getting to them in a timely manner to help out.

Do not buy this game.

column8:
Was a promising game, got it cheap so I didn't care. I virtually shelved it in my library and waited patiently for good updates to come but they never did, and the game was released unfinished just to take off that 'early access' status so the devs can stop the mandatory updates. Although the game still appears to be being updated, and the devs have said so. But for me, it just doesn't feel right to release the game at it's current state. A few months of development could have benefited them, especially the ratings. Right now I'm seeing 56% Positive 44% Negative, thanks to enhanced steam. and that's not good.

I don't blame the Early Access model, it's there for games like Kerbal Space Program, in which I would lose approx. 1000 hours of fun if the model hadn't existed. For games like Minecraft, Starbound, Arma 3, GalCiv 3, etc

In the future I would be more careful about buying early access games unless the ratings are 90% Positive and above, and the game is already feature complete, Thanks Enhanced Steam for that extra data!

Update: Now I'm seeing 50% positive 50% negative, which has more negatives than on my original review, i think it has gotten worse

column8:
Not really a game. Cool shipbuilder. I was told there would be a game, though. I was incredibly shocked when I saw the other day that they are claiming it's out of EA. It's plainly not, they just stopped working on it. Exactly the kind of thing that gives EA games a bad name.

Edit: It appears I was wrong to say that the devs had halted work on the game completely, thanks for the correction. As I looked into it it seems they have still been working on some monthly bug fixes and improvements. Though I don't think that any of the things I've seen listed in the change log really implore me to spend more time on the game even if many of the potential features that the devs have stated they'd like to add were to be added in the future, I'm happy to hear that the devs are still putting in some time.

While I'm glad to hear that the devs are still working on it, the statement of calling it a 1.00 version as well as the specific avoidance of promises about what will or will not make it into the game still turn me off enough to wish I had put my money somewhere else, though I admit there's an outside chance I could reinstall on a whim in a year or two and be pleasantly surprised.

So to sum up, the shipbuilding aspect is very well done and I'd say it's probably a lot less confusing than it might seem at first if you just take a few minutes to adjust yourself. It might still be a little obtuse at times, but you only have to check out the workshop to see how expansive it can be. However, the gameplay to my taste at least, still felt very underpolished and generally uninteresting to the point that I can't have a lot of hope it could ever be anything but outdated at best as of only one patch ago.

If I've missed anything, please feel free to let me know so I can correct it.

column8: Now that the game is no longer on "Early access" and there is an official final version, I can agree with many of the reviews here. The game is not what they promised (it's not even half of what they said and showed it would be). The random generated sandbox universes are great, but other than that, it's very empty and lacks a lot of depth. Looks like a failed attempt to make a mix between EVE online (only without online featues) and Freelancer gameplay. If I could ask for a refund, I would. This game is only worth it if it goes below 1€ during sales, and even so, I'm sure there will be a lot of much better games than this one for the same amount. So my advice is, don't waste your money on this.

column8:
Ich musste 2 mal gucken bis ich gemerkt habe das das Spiel gar nicht mehr Early Access ist, aber es spielt sich immer noch wie ein Early Access Spiel.

Der Schiff Editor ist nicht schlecht, und man findet sich in den auch sehr schnell rein. Der ist fast vergleichbar mit dem aus Kerbal Space Program. Ich habe das Spiel auf einen 1.8 Ghz Dual core mit 4GB unter Linux gespielt und es lief auf hohen Einstellungen flüssig.

Ändert aber nichts daran das das Spiel nach kurzer Zeit sehr schnell langweilig wird, es gibt ein Handelssystem, das kommt aber nicht an das der X-Serie heran.

Fazit: Wird viel zu schnell langweilig und kommt einem noch sehr unfertig vor.
column9:
I had to look twice before I realized the game wasn't in Early Access anymore, but it still plays like an Early Access game.

The ship editor isn't bad, and you get used to it very quickly. It's almost comparable to the one in Kerbal Space Program. I played the game on a 1.8 GHz dual-core processor with 4 GB of RAM under Linux, and it ran smoothly on high settings.

But that doesn't change the fact that the game gets boring very quickly after a short time. There is a trading system, but it doesn't compare to the one in the X-series.

Conclusion: It gets boring far too quickly and still feels very unfinished.

column8:
I watched this title for a long time. Had it on my wishlist and finally decided to take the plunge.  What's here is the beginning of something that could be truly great.  But it's simply that.  The beginning.  The game feels like it is still in early development not full release.

Pros 
+ The ability to design your own ship
+ Customizing the universe size and number of factions
+ Controls aren't overly complicated like many of it's space contemporaries

Cons
- The actual interface for designing your own ships is beyond complicated there is very little instruction.
- The tutorial is sub-par
- the "Career" mode seems like it is in it's infancy.
- To much time where you are doing nothing but waiting (3 or so minutes to mine out a single asteroid)

At THIS point I could not suggest this game to anyone unless they are willing to wait and see what the developers are going to do.  Make no mistake, this game may be in release but it is FAR from what any rational person would consider a "release state"

column8:
I like all the ideas of this game but implamentation is a bit rough. If you like me really enjoy building ships then it might be worth a look if your looking for an action packed space simulator you might be better off else where. Like most space games there is a good bit of time sink and like many ambisious indie projects the game feels a bit dated that said the ship building is well done and once you wrap your head around some of its quarks you can set up some prety cool ships.

The little punch line Build . Battle . Explore .... I think they got 1 out of 3 so cant give it a thumbs up at least not yet but I could see this game getting much better with future patches. Note this is a an early review ... I like to give a first impression  then add to it if I stick with the game so take it with a grain of salt it is a space game and the more time you put in the more fun you get out ... as a rule.

column9: Boring

column8:
Despite the negative reviews I decided it looked like the kind of game I would really enjoy... To be honest, I can't tell you if I enjoy the game or not, since I can't get past just how counter intuitive the ship building interface is. All I want to do is mirror a damn part. You have the tool, you click it, and as for mirroring? lets see, if by some miracle you do manage to get them to mirror.... they will be offset on the z axis, so they just wont align, and can you switch between the parts to do fine adjustment, nope, that button doesn't seem to do a damn thing. Either it's just not meant to do that, or whatever, but that's what I would think it would do... Dear devolopers, have you ever used any 3d modeling software? do you have any idea what 'mirror' means? I have spent the last hour since downloading it, trying to make a mirror image of a hull part. that's all I want to do. As it is, I'm going to just slap a bunch of parts together, throw some engines on it and call it good. I really hope that the actual game play isn't as counter intuitive as the ship building interface. Save your money folks, even on sale it isn't worth what I paid for it. Games are supposed to be fun, relaxing, enjoyable. Not vexing to the point of making any possible enjoyment moot.

Update: After another 3 hours of messing with the ship designer, I figured out a few tricks to actually make the parts line up as a mirror image of eachother, but naturally, it is not how you'd think you'd be able to pull it off. Anyways made the ship, launched, got a mission message, and it was very vague.

Managed to mine the required materials, and now I have no idea where to take them...

Suggestion for the developer, go play Freelancer. Compare what you attempted to do with the 'freelance' mode of the game. get a mission, it tells you where to go, add a module, it shows what it does, how it affects everything.

The KV interface is crap. It's a nice idea, but there's too much of the wrong information, and not enough of the right information. Buttons get hidden, the touch location changes, little bugs, that are obnoxious. 

It's nice that it's an open sandbox, and you get to choose where you get to go and when you go there, but what's the point if the game expects you to guess where you're suppoed to go to?

Save your money, and your frustration.

column8:
I own this game for a really long time, and I have owned it before it even was on steam, and boy is it good. 
its not easy, its not like you're going to build a rocket and land on the moon int your first ten minutes. No it will take you hours on getting it right. Once you're on the moon, you need even more time to get to the next planet. 

This is not a bad thing, it actually gives you a challange, and it forces you to really thing about what you're doing and what you want to get done, and how you're going to do it not the fastest way, but the most efficent way. 

If you like space games, that give you challange, than buy the game. If like the more easy stuff don't buy it. Its looks simpel but its not.

9/10 really good game, that will challange you, everytime. ( and little green men, lets not forget about the little green men... that died... alot....)

column8: Kinetic void is plainly one of those games that you should avoid. The graphics are sub-standard. They come out to be cartoony. Also the game is terribly optimized. When i got this 1 year ago, i could run it fine. With all the changes they made to the engine, I can't even run it at the lowest settings. These issues are just the smallest tip of this mountain of crap. First there are no mechanics in this game. Build a ship, get blown up, blow up other ships. There is no universe, there are no missions. There is no story. There is absolutely nothing to do, but build ships. However, the ship maker has gotten more and more complex to the point that a new palyer will rather just give up than play for 3 hours to find the correct modules to put on their ship. After those 3 hours, you can just wander around. The devs really disappointed me by releasing this hald-baked product. It is half-baked, all those nice promises on their EA page, lies....just lies. Even worse some of thsoe promises are being turned into DLC. Really? Really? Are EA and Ubisoft your inspirations? DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!
